info.title: F5 Distributed Cloud Services API for ves.io.schema.alert
info.description:
Alert may be generated based on the metrics or based on severity level in the logs. All alerts are scoped by 
tenant and namespace and tagged with the following default labels that can be used to fetch
the desired alerts.

"alertname" - Name of the alert. This uniquely identifies the alert rule/configuration that generated the alert.
"type" - Type of the alert. Type is used to associate alert to a configuration object or any user visible entity.
         For example, virtual host, virtual network, app_type, etc.
"identifier" - Identifier of the alert. For virtual-network, this would be the name of the virtual-network.
"severity" - Indicates the severity of the alert. Valid values are minor, major, critical.

Alert may have additional labels associated depending on the labels associated with the metric used to configure the alert rule.
Alerts can be queried by specifying one or more of the above labels in the match filter.
If the match filter is not specified, then all the alerts for the tenant and corresponding namespace in the request will be returned in the response.

get.description:
For system namespace, all the alerts for the tenant matching the filter specified in the request
will be returned in the response.

401.description: Returned when operation is not authorized

403.description: Returned when there is no permission to access resource

404.description: Returned when resource is not found

409.description: Returned when operation on resource is conflicting with current value

429.description: Returned when operation has been rejected as it is happening too frequently

500.description: Returned when server encountered an error in processing API

503.description: Returned when service is unavailable temporarily

504.description: Returned when server timed out processing request

parameters.name: namespace
parameters.description:
x-example: "value"
namespace to scope the listing of alerts.
when namespace = "system", all alerts for the tenant will be returned.

parameters.name: inactive
parameters.description:
x-example: "false"
If set to true, active alerts will not be returned in the response.

parameters.name: silenced
parameters.description:
x-example: "true"
show silenced alerts - alerts that are muted based on the matchers configured in the alert manager.

parameters.name: inhibited
parameters.description:
x-example: "false"
show inhibited alerts - alerts that are suppressed if certain other alerts are firing.

parameters.name: unprocessed
parameters.description:
x-example: "false"
show unprocessed alerts.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description:
x-example: "{alertname=\"HighDiskUsage\", severity=\"critical\"}"
List of matchers to filter alerts by.
Filtering via label matchers follows the same syntax and semantics as Prometheus.
syntax for filter := {[<matcher>]} 
<matcher> := <label_name><operator>"<label_value>"
<label_name> := string
  All alerts have the following default labels:
    "alertname", "identifier", "type", "severity"
<label_value> := string
<operator> := [ same as label match operators supported by prometheus - Please refer https://prometheus.io/docs/prometheus/latest/querying/basics ]
When more than one matcher is specified in the filter, then alerts matching ALL the matchers will be returned.

Optional: If not specified, then all the alerts for the tenant and namespace specified in the request will be returned.

get.description: Get alerts matching the filter for the given namespace.

503.description: Returned when service is unavailable temporarily

504.description: Returned when server timed out processing request

List of matchers to filter alerts by.
Filtering via label matchers follows the same syntax and semantics as Prometheus.
syntax for filter := {[<matcher>]} 
<matcher> := <label_name><operator>"<label_value>"
<label_name> := string
  All alerts have the following default labels:

get.description:
Get the history of alert notifications sent to the end-user between the start_time and end_time that matches the
filter specified in the request.

401.description: Returned when operation is not authorized

403.description: Returned when there is no permission to access resource

404.description: Returned when resource is not found

409.description: Returned when operation on resource is conflicting with current value

429.description: Returned when operation has been rejected as it is happening too frequently

500.description: Returned when server encountered an error in processing API

503.description: Returned when service is unavailable temporarily

504.description: Returned when server timed out processing request

parameters.name: namespace
parameters.description:
namespace

x-example: "ns1"
namespace to scope the listing of alerts.
For "system" namespace, all alerts for the tenant will be returned.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description:
x-example: "{alertname=\"HighDiskUsage\", severity=\"critical\"}"
List of matchers to filter alert by.
syntax for filter := {[<matcher>]}
<matcher> := <label_name><operator>"<label_value>"
<label_name> := string
  All alerts have the following default labels:
    "alertname", "identifier", "group", "severity"
<label_value> := string
<operator> := ["="|"!="|"=~"|"!~"]
  = : Select labels that are exactly equal to the provided string
  != : Select labels that are not equal to the provided string.
When more than one matcher is specified in the filter, then alerts matching ALL the matchers will be returned.

Optional: If not specified, then all the alerts for the tenant and namespace specified in the request will be returned.

parameters.name: start_time
parameters.description:
x-example: "2019-09-23T12:30:11.733Z"
fetch alerts whose timestamp >= start_time
format: unix_timestamp|rfc 3339

Optional: If not specified, then the start_time will be evaluated to end_time-10m
          If end_time is not specified, then the start_time will be evaluated to <current time>-10m

parameters.name: end_time
parameters.description:
x-example: "2019-09-24T12:30:11.733Z"
fetch alerts whose timestamp <= end_time
format: unix_timestamp|rfc 3339

Optional: If not specified, then the end_time will be evaluated to start_time+10m
          If start_time is not specified, then the end_time will be evaluated to <current time>

post.description:
Get summary/aggregation data for alerts in the given namespace.
For `system` namespace, all alerts for the tenant matching the query specified
in the request will be considered for aggregation.

401.description: Returned when operation is not authorized

403.description: Returned when there is no permission to access resource

404.description: Returned when resource is not found

409.description: Returned when operation on resource is conflicting with current value

429.description: Returned when operation has been rejected as it is happening too frequently

500.description: Returned when server encountered an error in processing API

503.description: Returned when service is unavailable temporarily

504.description: Returned when server timed out processing request

parameters.name: namespace
parameters.description:
namespace

x-example: "ns1"
namespace to scope the listing of alerts.
For "system" namespace, all alerts for the tenant will be returned.

get.description:
Scroll request is used to fetch large number of alert messages in multiple batches with each AlertsHistoryResponse
containing no more than 500 alerts. To scroll through more than 500 or all alert messages, one can use the
AlertsHistoryScrollRequest. Use the scroll_id returned in the AlertsHistoryResponse to fetch the next batch of alert messages and
one can continue this process till the scroll_id returned in the AlertsHistoryResponse is "" which indicates no more
alert messages to scroll.

401.description: Returned when operation is not authorized

403.description: Returned when there is no permission to access resource

404.description: Returned when resource is not found

409.description: Returned when operation on resource is conflicting with current value

429.description: Returned when operation has been rejected as it is happening too frequently

500.description: Returned when server encountered an error in processing API

503.description: Returned when service is unavailable temporarily

504.description: Returned when server timed out processing request

parameters.name: namespace
parameters.description:
namespace

x-example: "ns1"
fetch the alerts scoped by namespace

parameters.name: scroll_id
parameters.description:
x-example: "Vm9sdGVycmEgRWRnZSBQbGF0Zm9ybQ=="
Long Base-64 encoded string which can be used to retrieve next batch of alert messages.

post.description:

one can continue this process till the scroll_id returned in the AlertsHistoryResponse is "" which indicates no more

alertAggregationRequest.description:
x-displayName: "Aggregation Request"
Aggregation request to provide analytics data over the alert response
alertAggregationRequest.title: Aggregation Request

alertAlertsHistoryAggregationRequest.description: Request to get only aggregation data for alerts.
alertAlertsHistoryAggregationRequest.title: Alerts History Aggregation Request

aggs.description:
Aggregations provide summary/analytics data over the alert response. If the number of alerts that matched the query
 is large and cannot be returned in a single response message, user can get helpful insights/summary using aggregations.
 The aggregations are key'ed by user-defined aggregation name. The response will be key'ed with the same name.
 Optional
aggs.title: aggregations

end_time.description:
fetch alerts whose timestamp <= end_time
 format: unix_timestamp|rfc 3339

 Optional: If not specified, then the end_time will be evaluated to start_time+10m
           If start_time is not specified, then the end_time will be evaluated to <current time>

Example: ` "2019-09-24T12:30:11.733Z"`

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.query_time: true
end_time.title: end_time

filter.description:
List of matchers to filter alert by.
 syntax for filter := {[<matcher>]}
 <matcher> := <label_name><operator>"<label_value>"
 <label_name> := string
   All alerts have the following default labels:
     "alertname", "identifier", "group", "severity"
 <label_value> := string
 <operator> := ["="|"!="|"=~"|"!~"]
   = : Select labels that are exactly equal to the provided string
   != : Select labels that are not equal to the provided string.
 When more than one matcher is specified in the filter, then alerts matching ALL the matchers will be returned.

 Optional: If not specified, then all the alerts for the tenant and namespace specified in the request will be returned.

Example: ` "{alertname=\"HighDiskUsage\", severity=\"critical\"}"`
filter.title: filter

namespace.description:
namespace to scope the listing of alerts.
 For "system" namespace, all alerts for the tenant will be returned.

Example: ` "ns1"`
namespace.title: namespace

start_time.description:
fetch alerts whose timestamp >= start_time
 format: unix_timestamp|rfc 3339

 Optional: If not specified, then the start_time will be evaluated to end_time-10m
           If end_time is not specified, then the start_time will be evaluated to <current time>-10m

Example: ` "2019-09-23T12:30:11.733Z"`

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.query_time: true
start_time.title: start_time

aggs.description:
Aggregations provide summary/analytics data over the alerts response. If the number of alerts that matched the query
 is large and cannot be returned in a single response message, user can get helpful insights/summary using aggregations.
 The aggregation data is key'ed with the aggregation name specified in the request.
aggs.title: aggregations

total_hits.description:
total number of alerts that matched the query.

Example: ` "0"`
total_hits.title: total hits

alerts.description:
list of alerts that matched the filter. Contains no more than 500 alerts per response.

Example: ` "value"`
alerts.title: alerts

scroll_id.description:
Long Base-64 encoded string which can be used to retrieve next batch of alert messages using the scroll request.
 Empty scroll_id indicates no more messages to scroll (EOF).
 Note: scroll_id is valid only for 2 minutes. i.e., If one intend to retrieve next batch of the result, then the
       scroll request should be sent within 2 minutes upon receiving the response.

Example: ` "Vm9sdGVycmEgRWRnZSBQbGF0Zm9ybQ=="`
scroll_id.title: scroll_id

total_hits.description:
total number of alerts that matched the query.

Example: ` "100"`
total_hits.title: total hits

alertAlertsHistoryScrollRequest.description:
Scroll request is used to fetch large number of alert messages in multiple batches with each AlertsHistoryResponse
containing no more than 500 alerts. To scroll through more than 500 or all alert messages, one can use the
AlertsHistoryScrollRequest. Use the scroll_id returned in the AlertsHistoryResponse to fetch the next batch of alert messages and
one can continue this process till the scroll_id returned in the AlertsHistoryResponse is "" which indicates no more
alert messages to scroll.
alertAlertsHistoryScrollRequest.title: Alerts History Scroll Request

namespace.description:
fetch the alerts scoped by namespace

Example: ` "ns1"`
namespace.title: namespace

scroll_id.description:
Long Base-64 encoded string which can be used to retrieve next batch of alert messages.

Example: ` "Vm9sdGVycmEgRWRnZSBQbGF0Zm9ybQ=="`
scroll_id.title: scroll_id

alertCardinalityAggregation.description:
x-displayName: "Cardinality Aggregation"
Get approximate count of distinct values for the field in the alerts.
alertCardinalityAggregation.title: Cardinality Aggregation

alertDateAggregation.description:
x-displayName: "Date Aggregation"
Aggregate alerts based on timestamp in the alert
alertDateAggregation.title: Date Aggregation

step.description:
x-displayName: "Step"
x-required
x-example: "5m"

step is the resolution width, which determines the number of the data points [x-axis (time)] to be returned in the response.
The timestamps in the response will be t1=start_time, t2=t1+step, ... tn=tn-1+step, where tn <= end_time.
Format: [0-9][smhd], where s - seconds, m - minutes, h - hours, d - days
step.title: step

sub_aggs.description:
x-displayName: "Sub Aggregation"
This option provides sub-aggregation for each date bucket
sub_aggs.title: sub aggregation

alertDateSubAggregation.description:
x-displayName: "Date SubAggregation"
Aggregate alerts in each date bucket based on one of the sub aggregation types
alertDateSubAggregation.title: Date SubAggregation

alertFieldAggregation.description:
x-displayName: "Field Aggregation"
Aggregate alerts based on the key fields in the alert.
alertFieldAggregation.title: Field Aggregation

topk.description:
x-displayName: "TopK"
x-example: "5"

Number of top field values to be returned in the response.
Optional: If not specified, top 5 values will be returned in the response.
topk.title: topk

alertKeyField.description:
x-displayName: "Key Field"
Alerts can be aggregated based on these fields.

 - ALERTNAME: x-displayName: "Alertname"
 - IDENTIFIER: x-displayName: "Identifier"
 - GROUP: x-displayName: "Group"
 - SEVERITY: x-displayName: "Severity"
 - SITE: x-displayName: "Site"
 - STARTSAT: x-displayName: "StartsAt"
 - DESCRIPTION: x-displayName: "Description"
alertKeyField.title: Key Field

alertMultiFieldAggregation.description:
x-displayName: "MultiField Aggregation"
Aggregate alerts based on the key fields in the alert.
alertMultiFieldAggregation.title: MultiField Aggregation

fields.description:
x-displayName: "Field"
x-required

Field name by which the logs should be aggregated.
fields.title: field

sub_aggs.description:
x-displayName: "Sub Aggregations"
x-example: "top hits sub aggregation"

This option provides sub-aggregations for each field aggregation bucket.
sub_aggs.title: sub aggregations

topk.description:
x-displayName: "TopK"
x-example: "5"

Number of top field values to be returned in the response.
Optional: If not specified, top 5 values will be returned in the response.
topk.title: topk

alertMultiFieldSubAggregation.description:
x-displayName: "MultiFieldSubAggregation"
Aggregate events in each field bucket based on one of the sub aggregation types
alertMultiFieldSubAggregation.title: MultiFieldSubAggregation

schemaTrendSentiment.description:
x-displayName: "Trend Sentiment"
trend sentiment

 - TREND_SENTIMENT_NONE: x-displayName: "None"
 - TREND_SENTIMENT_POSITIVE: x-displayName: "Positive"
Indicates trend sentiment is positive
 - TREND_SENTIMENT_NEGATIVE: x-displayName: "Negative"
Indicates trend sentiment is negative.
schemaTrendSentiment.title: Trend Sentiment

schemaTrendValue.description:
x-displayName: "Trend Value"
Trend value contains trend value, trend sentiment and trend calculation description and window size.
schemaTrendValue.title: Trend Value

description.description:
x-displayName: "Description"
x-example: "Trend was calculated by comparing the avg of window size intervals of end-start Time and last window time interval"
description of the method used to calculate trend.
description.title: Description
